summary: react/promise v3 incompatibility causes unhandled promise rejections to trigger error_log calls with unpredictable side effects. The SDK cannot disable this behavior, and react/promise's handler mechanism is one-time rather than permanent, making the library unsuitable for async workflow coroutines until react/promise v3 is improved or a fork is created.
userImpact: Users experience unpredictable error_log side effects when workflows use rejected promises without handlers, and the SDK cannot disable this react/promise v3 behavior.
rootCause: react/promise v3 changed its error handling strategy to call error_log() for unhandled promise rejections, and its handler mechanism only works once rather than permanently, making it incompatible with SDK's coroutine-based workflow model.
proposedFix: Temporarily revert to react/promise v2.6.1 until react/promise v3 provides a permanent (not one-time) handler mechanism, or create and maintain a Temporal-compatible fork of react/promise.
workaround: Use react/promise v2.6.1 instead of v3
resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by downgrading or constraining dependency to react/promise v2 compatibility; long-term solution involves either upstream react/promise improvements or maintaining a fork.
keyQuote: when a rejected promise is completed, in which there is no exception handler, the error_log() function is called with the error text. The side effects of such behavior are unpredictable, and it is currently impossible to disable it.
